term: What Is the International Organization for Standardization (ISO)?

The International Organization for Standardization sets quality standards for products distributed across national borders.

The International Organization for Standardization (ISO) is a non-governmental group that develops and publishes quality standards for the production of goods that are sold internationally.

The ISO plays a role in facilitatingworld tradeby providing common standards of safety, reliability, and quality.

For theconsumer, ISO certification indicates that the company that made a product conforms to the minimum international standards set by ISO. ISO does not certify products but issues certification to companies whose processes meet its quality standards in particular areas.

Headquartered in Geneva, the ISO was founded in 1947.

It has its roots in the 1920s with the International Federation of the National Standardizing Associations (ISA), which was suspended during World War II. A United Nations committee proposed the current body to succeed the federation.

The ISO's influence extends to 167 countries, each of which has one representative from its national standards organization.

Members of ISO meet annually at a General Assembly to discuss the strategic objectives of the organization. In addition, there is a 20-person council with rotating membership that provides guidance and governance for the organization.

The organization's abbreviated name—ISO—is not an acronym. It derives from the ancient Greek wordísos, meaning equal or equivalent.

Because the organization would have different acronyms in different languages, its founders opted to call it by the short form ISO.

ISO develops and publishesstandardsfor a vast range of products, materials, and processes. Currently, the organization has defined more than 24,362 standards, which are included in the ISO Standards catalog.

The catalog is broken down into segments such ashealthcare, technology, railway engineering, jewelry, clothing, metallurgy, weapons, paint, civil engineering,agriculture, and aircraft. In addition to producing standards, ISO publishes technical reports, technical specifications, publicly available specifications, technical corrigenda, and guides.

In some cases, the ISO name is used to describe a product that conforms to an ISO standard. For example, the speed of film, or the sensitivity of a photographic film to light, is referred to by its ISO number (ISO 6, ISO 2240, and ISO 5800).

Some examples of ISO standards include the calibration of thermometers, food safety regulations, and the manufacturing of wine glasses. ISO standards also cover shoe sizes, musical pitches, security management, and environmental management.

The two most widely adopted ISO standards are ISO 9001 and ISO 14001.

ISO 9001 provides criteria for quality management systems. ISO 14001 provides criteria for environmental management systems.

ISO 9000 is a standard that focuses on quality management and quality assurance. Designed to apply to all industries, the standard is used by companies to develop and maintain their quality systems. Areas of focus include relationship management, customer focus, and leadership.

The ISO, or International Organization for Standardization, is responsible for setting uniform standards for products distributed around the globe. It creates uniform rule systems for quality management, health and safety, energy efficiency, and other factors.

Individual products are not ISO certified. The companies that produce them can achieve ISO certification for the processes they use in manufacturing them.
